Author: xeonrider#3120

Author: xeonrider#3120

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
@xeonrider you need a CORS proxy in front of it.
https://github.com/imylomylo/cors-anywhere
git clone
npm install
PORT=12345 node server.js

then your axios requests will look like: `http://your.cors.proxy:port/127.0.0.1:7771`
e.g. 
```
    console.log("AppCoins Created");
    axios
      .get("http://" + process.env.VUE_APP_WEBHOST + ":" + process.env.VUE_APP_WEBPORT + "/" + process.env.VUE_APP_MMBOTHOST + ":" + process.env.VUE_APP_MMBOTPORT + "/api/v1/legacy/mm2/get_enabled_coins")
      .then(response => {
        console.log("MYLO" + JSON.stringify(response.data.result));
```

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: e.g. http://cors.mydomain.com:12345/127.0.0.1:7771/

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
you can make rpc-proxy for your program with something like this if you want ready implementation:
https://github.com/bitpay/bitcoind-rpc
https://github.com/drazisil/node-bitcoin-rpc

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: your end-goal is just to send request to komodod and receive json output from it

Author: TonyL#3577
xeonrider#3120
Content: @TonyL so Komodo uses bitcoin rpc?

Author: xeonrider#3120
Content: like a standard?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
```
  var config = {
    protocol: 'http',
    user: 'user',
    pass: 'pass',
    host: '127.0.0.1',
    port: '18332',
  };``` just set correct params here (7771 port and use user name password from .komodo.conf)

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: this bitcoin-rpc is nothing special - it's just auth standartized way

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: and then sending requests and fetching json output from daemon

Author: xeonrider#3120
Content: oh

Author: xeonrider#3120
Content: thats pretty neat

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: so it should work with komodod as well - just set port, username/password and issue rpc calls

Author: xeonrider#3120
Content: so, I don't need axios at all

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: for example for my python things I'm using this one: https://github.com/barjomet/slick-bitcoinrpc

Author: xeonrider#3120
Content: and the daemon returns a json, right?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: not sure how it's on JS but on python I can use standart `requests` lib lets say and just execute get calls - one above is just faster

Author: xeonrider#3120
Content: so my app can consume that easily

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: yes, daemon returns json

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: in some calls it might be number or bool

Content: Yep

Content: https://github.com/tonymorony/komodo-cctools-python/blob/master/lib/tuilib.py#L129 token creation method for terminal interface for example

Author: jorian#4555
Content: you can launch your own chain using komodod, no need for antara composer

Author: jorian#4555
Content: the composer is just an easy way to do it

Author: jorian#4555
Content: but if you know rogue, then you can do start a chain using CLI i guess 😄

Author: xeonrider#3120

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: you can find some guides on chain launch here: https://developers.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/smart-chains/introduction-to-smart-chain-documentation.html

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: in general it's super simple: just start daemon on one node, start daemon on second node with connection to first one - thats it. Composer is kinda corporate thing in my understanding, for your CCs research purposes you can setup chain on your own

Author: jorian#4555
Content: the command line is your access to your wallet

Author: jorian#4555
Content: `./komodo-cli -ac_name=COINNAME getinfo` would give you your balance

Author: jorian#4555
Content: but if you want a fancy graphical user interface, you need to get listed in VRSC Agama, Chameleon, Pungo, or any other wallet

Author: jorian#4555
Content: or clone their software and maintain a wallet yourself
